tier_1_determinative.mischief_act: Causing damage to a motorcycle during a quarrel.
tier_1_determinative.damage_amount: Not specified, but the damage was significant enough to be included in a police complaint.

tier_4_procedural.case_number: Criminal Bail Application No. 191 of 2022 and Criminal Bail Application No. 3090 of 2021
tier_4_procedural.case_title: Akshay Rajendra Parache versus The State of Maharashtra
tier_4_procedural.court_name: High Court of Judicature at Bombay
tier_4_procedural.appellant_or_petitioner: Akshay Rajendra Parache and Harsh Kishor Babu
tier_4_procedural.counsel_for_appellant: Mr. Aniket Vagal a/w Mr. Kunal Pednekar for Akshay Rajendra Parache; Mr. Hitesh Shah for Harsh Kishor Babu.
tier_4_procedural.counsel_for_respondent: Mr. N. B. Patil, APP for the State.
tier_4_procedural.sections_invoked: Sections 302, 395, 397, 143, 147, 148, 149 of IPC and MCOC Act sections
tier_4_procedural.acts_and_sections: Indian Penal Code (IPC) sections 302, 395, 397, 143, 147, 148, 149 and Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act (MCOC Act) sections 3(1)(i), 3(1)(ii), 3(2), 3(3), and 3(4)

residual_details.additional_facts: The applicants were part of a group accused of organized crime activities including robbery, theft, and extortion. A significant aspect of the case involves the alleged involvement of the accused in a gang and their activities, leading to serious charges under the MCOC Act. The bail applications were allowed due to lack of evidence directly linking the applicants to the crime scene or the assault.
